latestVersion.versionNote:
This study was first completed in 2007 & underwent extensive reviews before being accepted for publication in fall 2009.  It represents my first cross-cutting cleavages dataset, which has now been super-ceded by the more extensive dataset in Political Analysis (PA).  "Cross-fragmentation" is now labeled "Cross-fractionalization" in the PA dataset.

The ideas relating to civil war have further been developed using the new dataset.  Indeed, the article coauthored with Josh Gubler (JCR) uses crosscutting measures between ethnicity & region & income.  It is also theoretically richer.

Nevertheless, this paper remains at the heart of my developing ideas & empirical measures relating to the resurrection of cross-cutting cleavages in the political science literature.  One of its primary purposes was to show that, contrary to Fearon and Laitin (2003), ethnic fractionalization by itself was a poor proxy for ethnic diversity and that diversity does affect civil war when measured more richly.
